newsitem.title: USA: Natgas futures open up on pipeline news, then ease.
newsitem.headline: Natgas futures open up on pipeline news, then ease.

text.p: NYMEX Henry Hub natgas futures opened higher Thursday after news of a pipeline rupture surfaced, but then softened when TransCanada said no deliveries were affected and cash prices eased, sources said.
At 1130 EST, January was 5.3 cents lower at $3.44 per million British thermal units after hitting a high of $3.565, up 7.2 cents. February fell 4.9 cents to $3.19.

"Cash was softer early, but there are a lot of people pulling gas out of storage already and the weather looks supportive," one futures source said, noting low inventories and cooler forecasts are preventing January from diving.
American Gas Association said Wednesday U.S. gas stocks fell by 72 billion cubic feet (bcf) to 75 percent of capacity, still 214 bcf, or eight percent, below year-ago levels.
In the Consuming Region East, stocks declined by 40 bcf to 84 percent full.
Counteracting the lower-than-expected storage drawdown was news that one of TransCanada Pipelines three 30-inch gas pipelines ruptured late Wednesday near Vermillion Bay in western Ontario.
However, the company said no deliveries were affected since they were able to re-route the gas along an adjacent pipeline.

Traders said there was major support in January was at $3.19-3.20, then $3.11 and $3.04. Resistance was seen in the low-$3.50s and then at $3.70. Major resistance was pegged at the contract high of $3.80.

In the cash market, Gulf Coast prices were talked early in the mid-$3.30s, down about five cents from Wednesday. Midcontinent prices were steady to lower in the low-to-mid $3.30s, while Appalachian gas traded in the high-$3.50s to mid-$3.60s, down more than 10 cents on the day.

A storm is moving into the Northeast this weekend, forecasters said, likely to bring widespread precipitation and wind. The six- to 10-day outlook is calling for temperatures throughout most of the U.S, excluding the East Coast, to be below- to much below-normal.
NYMEX Permian basin natgas futures were untraded after settling Wednesday at $3.25, up 20 cents.
Permian cash prices on Wednesday were around $3.25.
NYMEX Alberta natgas futures were also untraded following Wednesday's settlement at $1.63.
Physical December gas at the AECO storage hub traded Wednesday around $1.50 per million British thermal units.
On the KCBT, January dipped to $3.285, down six cents. Open interest for December 11 rose by 48 to 2,668. The East/West spread widened by 0.7 cent to 15.5 cents (NYMEX premium).
